image.altText: Mother holds child in front of hospital equipment as child cries

items.synopsis: Hundreds of people are believed to be dead after a blast at a crammed Gaza hospital that Israel and Palestinian militants are blaming on each other, while regional leaders postpone meetings with Joe Biden ahead of his visit to Israel.

title.children: Israel and Palestinian militants blame each other after hospital blast kills hundreds in Gaza

image.altText: Three people move a stretcher with a man on it who is bandaged up.

items.synopsis: The meeting has been cancelledÂ as the US president travels to Israel. Follow live for the latest updates.

title.children: Jordan cancels summit with Biden and Egyptian and Palestinian leaders amid claims of strike on Gaza hospital

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the government is planning an additional departure flight today for Australians trying to leave Tel Aviv for Dubai. A government assisted-departure flight landed in Sydney from Dubai last night, carrying 222 passengers, including 164 Australians. Meanwhile, 46 registered Australians remain in Gaza, with the Rafah border crossing with Egypt still closed. Senator Wong says the government is also supporting departure options for Australians in the West Bank, including working with partners to arrange transport to Jordan. She says more than 1,500 Australians have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian government planning another repatriation flight today

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the government is planning an additional departure flight today for Australians trying to leave Tel Aviv for Dubai.
A government assisted-departure flight landed in Sydney from Dubai last night, carrying 222 passengers, including 164 Australians.
Meanwhile, 46 registered Australians remain in Gaza, with the Rafah border crossing with Egypt still closed.
Senator Wong says the government is also supporting departure options for Australians in the West Bank, including working with partners to arrange transport to Jordan.
She says more than 1,500 Australians have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reuters news agency says protests have been staged at Israel's embassies in Turkey and Jordan and near the US embassy in Lebanon, where security forces fired tear gas toward demonstrators. There have also been protests in Yemen's south-western city of Taz, as well as in the Moroccan capital Rabat and Iraq's capital, Baghdad. Protests also took place in front of the French embassy in Tunis, Tunisia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hospital blast ignites protests in West Bank and around Middle East

children.content: The Reuters news agency says protests have been staged at Israel's embassies in Turkey and Jordan and near the US embassy in Lebanon, where security forces fired tear gas toward demonstrators.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jordan has cancelled a summit it was to host in Amman on Wednesday with US President Joe Biden and the Egyptian and Palestinian leaders to discuss the situation in Gaza, the country's foreign minister, Ayman Safadi, said. Biden was expected to meet the Arab leaders following a solidarity visit to Israel. Reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jordan cancels summit with Biden and Egyptian and Palestinian leaders

children.content: Jordan has cancelled a summit it was to host in Amman on Wednesday with US President Joe Biden and the Egyptian and Palestinian leaders to discuss the situation in Gaza, the country's foreign minister, Ayman Safadi, said.
Biden was expected to meet the Arab leaders following a solidarity visit to Israel.

image.altText: A composite image of Jack Ginnivan, Ivan Soldo and Esava Ratugolea.

items.synopsis: It all comes down to deadline day for the AFL trade period, with some big moves and late surprises on the cards before the window shuts tonight. Get the latest news, analysis and discussion in our live blog.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We've slowly chipped away at the list over the past week and a half, and now I expect to see almost every name left find a new club by bedtime tonight: Brandon Zerk-Thatche r to Port Adelaide Esava Ratugolea to Port Adelaide Ivan Soldo to Port Adelaide Jordan Sweet to Port Adelaide Xavier Duursma to Essendon Jacob Koschitzke to Richmond Mabior Chol to Hawthorn Jack Gunston to Hawthorn Massimo D'Ambrosio to Hawthorn Jack Ginnivan to Hawthorn Brandon Ryan to Hawthorn Elijah Hollands to Carlton Jack Billings to ?? Scott Lycett to ?? Aside from the question-mark pair at the bottom there, I reckon all the others get done today. I'll be going through every individual deal one by one throughout the morning as we wait for that embargo to lift.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The deals to be done today

children.content: We've slowly chipped away at the list over the past week and a half, and now I expect to see almost every name left find a new club by bedtime tonight:
Aside from the question-mark pair at the bottom there, I reckon all the others get done today.
I'll be going through every individual deal one by one throughout the morning as we wait for that embargo to lift.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's no ordinary day of trade period. Things work a little differently on deadline day. Representatives from clubs will recommence discussions this morning before they all convene at Docklands Stadium this afternoon No trades can be confirmed or announced until 3pm AEDT A member from each club's list management team will front the media throughout the afternoon The trade period officially ends at 7.30pm AEDT. All paperwork must be lodged with the AFL by that time for a deal to be ratified
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How does deadline day work?

children.content: It's no ordinary day of trade period. Things work a little differently on deadline day.
Representatives from clubs will recommence discussions this morning before they all convene at Docklands Stadium this afternoon
No trades can be confirmed or announced until 3pm AEDT
A member from each club's list management team will front the media throughout the afternoon
The trade period officially ends at 7.30pm AEDT.
All paperwork must be lodged with the AFL by that time for a deal to be ratified

items.synopsis: Local shares are set to open slightly higher, after a mixed session on Wall Street.Â Follow the day's financial news and insights in our live blog.

title.children: RBA governor Michele Bullock discusses inflation ahead of November rates meeting, ASX to open higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As predicted, the local sharemarket has opened slightly higher at 10:30am (AEDT). The ASX 200 is up 0.2% to 7,068 points and the broader All Ordinaries is up about the same to 7,258 points. Debt collector Credit Corp Group is down a massive -22% (yes you read that correctly) after announcing an impairment related to its US debt ledger assets. It's likely to produce a one-off reduction in net profit after tax of $45 million. Whitehaven Coal has entered into a trading halt after BHP announced it was the preferred bidder for its Queensland coal mines. The top five movers: Paladin Energy +2.7% Capricorn Metals +2.7% Reliance Worldwide Corporation +2% A2 Milk Company +1.7% Inghams Group +1.5% The bottom five movers: Credit Corp Group -22% Hub24 -2.3% AMP -2.2% James Hardie Industries -1.8% Atlas Arteria Group -1.6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens slightly higher

children.content: local sharemarket has opened slightly higher
All Ordinaries is up about the same to 7,258 points
Credit Corp Group is down a massive -22%
(yes you read that correctly) after announcing an impairment related to its US debt ledger assets.
It's likely to produce a one-off reduction in net profit after tax of $45 million.
Whitehaven Coal has entered into a trading halt
after BHP announced it was the preferred bidder for its Queensland coal mines.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Michele Bullock has also discussed the housing market, and said she's been surprised by how it has bounced back from its initial declines. "The housing market has surprised me a bit â¦ when COVID first hit housing prices actually declined, and then after a few months they shot up, and they shot up about 20, 25%," she said. "They really rose very, very sharply, and I should add this happened all around the world. "Now they're [house prices] back to where they were. "There's a few things going on here â¦ one is that there's difficulties in construction of new housing â¦ the cost of new housing has risen quite sharply, and that I think has made the equation between building a new house and buying an existing house has changed somewhat. "The equation between 'do I buy my own home or do I rent?' also shifts somewhat." She also mentioned that household size during the pandemic had declined significantly as people decided they wanted an office to work from home, no longer share with flatmates, or move further out. "A whole lot of decisions went into people having more housing stock per person," she said. "I might get the number wrong, but I saw something to the effect that that the decline was in effect the same as an additional 140,000 homes, just by that decline in household side. "Now household side has turned around a bit, and you would expect it to because rents are rising ... but nevertheless I think average household size has been another factor here that's impacted the supply and demand imbalance in the housing market."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bullock 'surprised' by resilient housing market and rising house prices

children.content: Michele Bullock has also discussed the housing market, and said she's been surprised by how it has bounced back from its initial declines.
"The housing market has surprised me a bit â¦ when COVID first hit housing prices actually declined, and then after a few months they shot up, and they shot up about 20, 25%," she said.
"They really rose very, very sharply, and I should add this happened all around the world.
"Now they're [house prices] back to where they were.

"There's a few things going on here â¦ one is that there's difficulties in construction of new housing â¦ the cost of new housing has risen quite sharply, and that I think has made the equation between building a new house and buying an existing house has changed somewhat.
"The equation between 'do I buy my own home or do I rent?' also shifts somewhat."
She also mentioned that household size during the pandemic had declined significantly as people decided they wanted an office to work from home, no longer share with flatmates, or move further out.
"A whole lot of decisions went into people having more housing stock per person," she said.
"I might get the number wrong, but I saw something to the effect that that the decline was in effect the same as an additional 140,000 homes, just by that decline in household side.

"Now household side has turned around a bit, and you would expect it to because rents are rising ... but nevertheless I think average household size has been another factor here that's impacted the supply and demand imbalance in the housing market."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Michele Bullock was also asked about how she will approach the media in her role as RBA governor, in response to how her predecessor, Philip Lowe, was treated. She replied that dealing with the media isn't her prime focus in her job, but noted that the media have been "very focused on interest rates are rising" by certain parts of the community "who are very hurt by that". She said the RBA's independence from the government allows for the central bank to make "difficult decisions". She also gets a laugh from the crowd when she noted that Mr Lowe "copped a lot" of heat from the media before saying she thinks he got "knocked off" by former Qantas CEO Alan Joyce.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Media criticism of former RBA governor Philip Lowe got 'knocked off' by ex-Qantas CEO Alan Joyce

children.content: Michele Bullock was also asked about how she will approach the media in her role as RBA governor, in response to how her predecessor, Philip Lowe, was treated.

She replied that dealing with the media isn't her prime focus in her job, but noted that the media have been "very focused on interest rates are rising" by certain parts of the community "who are very hurt by that".
She said the RBA's independence from the government allows for the central bank to make "difficult decisions".
She also gets a laugh from the crowd when she noted that Mr Lowe "copped a lot" of heat from the media before saying she thinks he got "knocked off" by former Qantas CEO Alan Joyce.
